tutorial.title: Linktree - Part 2
tutorial.descriptionContent: Now that you've set up the HTML of your Linktree-style page, it's time to make it pop! In this part, we'll use CSS to style and bring personality to your page.

executableContent.instructions:
Welcome back to the **Linktree** project! Before we start styling the webpage, we need to do some housekeeping. As you know by now, the content of a webpage needs to go between `html` and `body` tags.

1. Add an opening `html` tag (`<html>`) at the top of your HTML document.
2. Add a closing `html` tag (`</html>`) at the bottom of your HTML document.
2. Below the opening `html` tag,  add an opening `body` (`<body>`) tag.
3. Above the closing `html` tag, add a closing `body` (`</body>`) tag.

hints.title: Order of tags
hints.content:
The resulting code should look similar to this:
   ```HTML
   <html>
    <body>
     ...
    </body>
   </html>
   ```

executableContent.instructions:
Some elements provide information to the browser but aren't displayed on the web page. The `head` element contains such elements and is placed inside the `html` element above your `body` element.

1. Create the `head` opening and closing tags at the top of your HTML document.

executableContent.instructions:
Now, it's finally time for some CSS.

1. Create a `link` element inside the existing `head` element.
2. Include these two attributes and values inside the `link` tag:
    - `href="style.css"`
    - `rel="stylesheet"`

Your code should look something like this
```HTML
<head>
 <link href="style.css" rel="stylesheet"/>
</head>
```

executableContent.instructions:
You can also apply styles to your entire web page by targeting the `body` element.

1. Code a new rule to target the `body` element and set:
    - `background-color` to a color like `slateblue ` 
    - `font-family` to  a font such as `'Trebuchet MS'`
    -  text `color` to a color that has a high contrast to your background color (if you chose `slateblue` for the background, try `white`.)

hints.title: Are we using cascading?
hints.content: When you change how the `<body>` element looks using CSS in an HTML document, it affects many other parts of the webpage, too. This is because the `<body>` element holds a lot of the content and styles applied directly to it _cascade_ to other elements contained within.

executableContent.instructions:
Next up, let's style our links to make them more visually appealing.

   -  `background-color` to `white`
   -  `font-size` to `20px`
   -  `border-radius` to `10px`
   -  `padding` to `10px`

hints.title: Why this style?
hints.content:
This CSS styles anchor links as button-like elements. 
They feature a white background, centered text, no underlines, and a readable font size. 
The full-width display, padding, rounded corners, and margin spacing contribute to a visually appealing, clickable appearance in line with common button design principles.

executableContent.instructions:
We can make the links look a bit nicer, still. Some of those changes might feel a bit odd, but bear with us; you'll understand what's happening behind the scenes very soon!

1. Add the following declarations to the `a` rule:
   -  `display` to `block`
   -  `text-align` to `center`
   -  `margin` to `10px`
   -  `color` to `slateblue`
2. Add the following declaration to the `body` rule:
   -  `text-align` to `center`
